Fischer–Tropsch synthesis via CO2 hydrogenation represents a promising route for the direct conversion of CO2 into value-added hydrocarbons, contributing to carbon recycling and sustainable fuel production. In conventional Fe-based catalysts, alkali and alkaline earth metals function as electron promoters for Fe, enhancing Fe carbide formation and thereby facilitating the production of C2+ hydrocarbons. Furthermore, transition metals (e.g. Zn, Cu, Mn, Co) enhance carbon chain growth and improve the durability of Fe-based catalysts. This study proposes that abundant interfaces among Cu, Mg, and Fe species are crucial for enhancing CO2 conversion. An alumina-supported CuMgFe-type hydrotalcite (CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3) was developed, yielding highly dispersed metal species that formed ∼5 nm nanoparticles after reduction and providing twice the external surface area of the physical mixture (CuMgFe-HT + Al2O3). This catalyst provided a high interface of Cu and other metal oxides, improving CO2 adsorption. Moreover, the Fe species in CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 exhibited a more electron-rich state than those in impregnated CuMgFe/Al2O3, leading to enhanced reducibility of Fe. The CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 achieved a CO2 conversion of 43 %, with CH4 selectivity of 23 % and C5+ hydrocarbon selectivity of 39 %. In contrast, the impregnated CuMgFe/Al2O3 showed higher CH4 selectivity (35 %) and lower C5+ selectivity (24 %). Furthermore, CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 inhibited the sintering of nano-metal particles and exhibited higher catalytic performance with enhanced stability. The interface between Cu and metal oxides (FeOx and MgO) contributes to the formation and maintenance of Fe carbides, enhancing C–C coupling reactions and providing active sites that can produce C5+ hydrocarbons with high stability. The utilization of CO2 not only addresses these challenges but also enables carbon recycling, thereby reducing the dependence on fossil resources. Among various approaches, CO2 hydrogenation is considered one of the most promising reactions due to the thermodynamic stability of CO2, which requires a co-reactant with a higher Gibbs free energy to drive the reaction forward [4,5]. Conventionally, the conversion of CO2 to hydrocarbons involves two main steps: the hydrogenation of CO2 to CO via the reverse water–gas shift (RWGS) reaction, followed by Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) using CO and H2. However, RWGS requires high energy consumption to achieve high CO2 conversion due to thermodynamic equilibrium [6,7]. In contrast, direct CO2–to–hydrocarbon FTS bypasses this equilibrium constraint and enables hydrocarbon production with lower energy consumption compared to the conventional two-step process. Nevertheless, conventional iron-based catalysts for direct CO2 FTS exhibit poor CO2 adsorption capacity and a low CO2/H2 surface ratio, which promotes the excessive hydrogenation of CO2 and favors methane formation over C2+ hydrocarbons [8]. Therefore, modification of Fe species is essential to suppress methanation and enhance C–C coupling. Electronic promoters, including alkali metals (e.g., Na, K, Li, Cs, etc.) [9–15] and alkaline earth metals (e.g., Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba, etc.) [16,17] have been shown to facilitate electron transfer to Fe. This electron transfer enhances CO adsorption and weakens the C−O bonds, thereby promoting the reducibility and carburization of Fe species, which facilitates the formation and stabilization of the FeCx active phase. Alkali and alkaline earth metals also improve CO2 adsorption. Moreover, the electronic effect inhibits the H2 dissociation and favors the formation of olefins and long-chain hydrocarbons. Alkali and alkaline earth metals also improve CO2 adsorption, thereby contributing to CO2 conversion. Specifically, MgO surface activates CO2 into carbonate substances, and Mgx-H complexes exhibit stronger electron-donating effects [18], which promote the formation of *HCOO, a critical intermediate species in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. Nevertheless, the relatively high reaction temperature of the process suppresses chain growth reactions, resulting in the formation of light olefins over these iron-based catalysts, which often suffer from poor stability. Efforts to enhance carbon chain growth and improve the durability of iron-based catalysts have focused on doping with transition metals such as zinc (Zn) [8,19–23], copper (Cu) [24–29], manganese (Mn) [30–32], and cobalt (Co) [33–36]. Specifically, the CuFeO₂ spinel catalyst exhibited high selectivity for C5+ hydrocarbons (66.3 %) and low selectivity for CH4 (2.4 %), with a CO2 conversion rate of 17.3 % [26]. In contrast, Fe2O3 showed significantly lower C5+ selectivity (2.3 %) and higher CH4 selectivity (60.2 %). Dispersed Cu and Fe on Al2O3 improved CO2 conversion to 28.5 % [27]; however, C–C coupling was suppressed, as indicated by a reduced C2+ hydrocarbon selectivity (53 %), leading to an increased CH4 selectivity of 24 %. We propose that metal dispersibility is a key factor in enhancing the synergistic interactions between metal components. Therefore, in this study, we focus on utilizing the hydrotalcite structure to improve metal dispersion. Hydrotalcite, a type of layered double hydroxide (LDH), is composed of positively charged brucite-like layers with interlayer anions and water molecules. Its structure is commonly represented by the general formula [M2 + 1-xM3+ x(OH)2](An-)x/n ·m H2O, where M²⁺ denotes a divalent metal cation (e.g., Mg2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Mn2+), M3+ is a trivalent metal cation (e.g., Al3+, Fe3+, Cr3+), An- is the interlayer anion, x is the molar ratio of M3+ to the total metal content (M2+ + M3+), and m is the number of water molecules [37]. Additionally, hydrotalcites containing transition metals such as Cu, Ni, or Co are calcined and subsequently reduced to generate highly dispersed metal nanoparticles. The resulting hydrotalcite-derived catalysts exhibited superior catalytic performance, outperforming conventional supported metal catalysts [38–40]. However, the hydrotalcite structure exhibits a tendency to agglomerate, which may hinder the accessibility of the active sites and suggests potential for further improvement. In our previous study, we developed a catalyst comprising highly dispersed hydrotalcite supported on zeolite for the isomerization and dehydration of glucose [41]. This bifunctional catalyst enables both reactions to occur simultaneously, as the close proximity of acid and base sites facilitates the uniform dispersion of hydrotalcite on the support. In this study, we tried to prepare CuMgFe-type hydrotalcite stacked on alumina and calcined and reduced to form the highly dispersed metal species. The potential of this active site species for facilitating the direct CO₂ FT synthesis reaction was explored. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and materials Aluminum Isopropoxide (>98.0 %) was acquired from Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd. The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for 30 min to ensure complete dissolution and hydrolysis. Subsequently, aqueous ammonia was slowly added to the mixture, and the suspension was stirred for an additional 21 h to facilitate gel formation. The obtained gel was thoroughly washed with distilled water and then sonicated in acetone for 30 min to remove residual organics. The sample was dried overnight in an oven at 120 °C, followed by calcination at 550 °C in air for 12 h to obtain alumina, which was used as a catalyst support. 2.2.2 Synthesis of CuMgFe-type hydrotalcite Hydrotalcite (HT) with a Cu/Mg/Fe molar ratio of 1:2:1 was synthesized via a co-precipitation method. Solution A was prepared by dissolving 0.59 g of Na2CO3 in 100 mL of distilled water. Solution B consisted of 0.51 g of Cu(NO3)2·6 H2O, 1.10 g of Mg(NO3)2·6 H2O, and 0.85 g of Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O dissolved in 200 mL of distilled water. Solution B was added dropwise to Solution A under vigorous stirring at 600 rpm and 50 °C, while maintaining the pH at 10 ± 0.5 using a NaOH solution. A light green precipitate gradually formed during the addition. After the addition was complete, the resulting slurry was aged at 50 °C for 1 h, then cooled to room temperature. The solid was collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with distilled water, and sonicated in acetone for 30 min. The sample was subsequently filtered and dried in an oven overnight at 120 °C. Finally, the dried powder was calcined at 500 °C for 5 h in air to obtain the mixed metal oxide catalyst, designated as “CuMgFe-HT”. For comparison, a hydrotalcite sample with an Mg/Fe molar ratio of 2:1 (without Cu) was synthesized following the same procedure and was designated as “MgFe-HT”. 2.2.3 Synthesis of alumina-supported hydrotalcite-derived catalyst 2.0 g alumina was sonicated in 100 mL of distilled water for 30 min to ensure uniform suspension (Solution A). When CuMgFe-HT was supported on alumina (CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3), diffraction peaks corresponding to the hydrotalcite phase were also observed (Fig. 1b), whereas calcined and reduced sample exhibited peak of Fe metal in addition to alumina. This morphology remained unchanged after calcination. In contrast, after hydrogen reduction, the plate- and needle-like features disappeared, and metal particles were observed. Hydrotalcite is known to possess a layered double hydroxide (LDH) structure composed of divalent and trivalent metal cations, with interlayer anions (such as CO3 2-) and water molecules, as well as hydroxyl groups on the surface of the layers. Upon calcination, these hydroxyl groups were removed, and the layered structure was decomposed, resulting to the formation of mixed metal oxides (MMOs) [43,44]. When the resulting MMOs contains a highly reducible metal species, subsequent hydrogen reduction forms well-dispersed metal nanoparticles (NPs). These results indicate that the CuMgFe-HT-derived morphology was retained even after transformation into a mixed metal oxides by calcination. The Cu, Mg, and Fe species in the resulting MMOs are likely to remain highly dispersed, resembling their distribution in the original hydrotalcite structure. These results suggest that supporting CuMgFe-HT on Al2O3 suppress the aggregation of CuMgFe-HT, thereby potentially improving accessibility of active sites derived from the CuMgFe-type hydrotalcite. 3.2 Characterization of surface sites and electronic structure CO2 direct Fischer–Tropsch (FT) synthesis involves sequential reactions occurring over distinct metal sites: CO₂ is first reduced to CO over Cu, followed by hydrocarbon formation over Fe carbides. Therefore, minimizing the distance between Cu and Fe sites may be critical for facilitating efficient CO diffusion and enhancing catalytic activity. For example, H2–TPD is commonly employed to evaluate the metal–oxide interface. In the H2-TPD profile, the peak observed between 100 and 350 °C is assigned to weak H2 adsorption on metal site [45,46]. Additionally, peaks in the range of 250–350 °C are attributed to –OH groups associated with non-reduced Fe oxides [47]. A peak at higher temperatures (>350 °C) is attributed to hydrogen spillover on the surface of metal clusters (Cu0 and Fe0) and metal oxides [45,46,48,49]. The H2–TPD profile of Fe/Al2O3 shows H2 desorption in the range of 250–700 °C ( Fig. 5). The amount of desorbed H2 above 350 °C is 102 μmol gcat −1, as summarized in Table 3, which is higher than that of Cu/Al2O3 containing easily reducible Cu species. For Fe/Al2O3, these desorption peaks may be attributed to H₂ spillover on Fe oxides, since nearly all Fe species remain in the oxide state after hydrogen reduction at 400 °C [46]. In contrast, introducing Cu and Mg to Fe species significantly increased H₂ adsorption (274 μmol gcat −1) at temperatures above 350 °C. This enhancement was more pronounced than that observed with the addition of Mg only to Fe species (126 μmol gcat −1). These results indicate that H2 adsorption and dissociation on Cu sites were promoted, thereby accelerating H2 spillover into metal oxides such as FeOx [46,50]. Furthermore, the hydrotalcite-derived Cu, Mg, and Fe species on Al2O3 promoted H2 adsorption, supporting that this structure increases the interface between metallic Cu and metal oxides (FeOx and MgO). In contrast, the physically mixed hydrotalcite exhibited lower H2 adsorption compared to the hydrotalcite-dispersed Al2O3. These results indicate that the well-dispersed hydrotalcite structure on alumina effectively utilizes its high metal dispersion capability, providing abundant and accessible interfacial sites. CO2–TPD analysis was performed to investigate CO2 adsorption at the interfacial sites between Cu and metal oxides, which are considered to play a key role in catalytic performance. The CO2–TPD profile exhibited desorption peaks in the temperature ranges of 100–175 °C, 175–400 °C, and above 400 °C, corresponding to weak (α), moderate (β), and strong (γ) basic sites, respectively [51]. The β peaks observed at 175–400 °C in the CO2–TPD profile of hydrotalcite are attributed to bidentate carbonate species coordinated on both M1 2+–O2- and M2 3+–O2- pairs, which facilitate as moderate-strength basic sites [52–56]. This CO2 adsorption primarily occurs at the interfaces in multi-metal systems, such as Cu–ZnO and hydrotalcite-derived materials. Additionally, the γ peak observed above 400 °C is attributed to the adsorption of CO2 strongly bound to low-coordination O2- anions, which act as strong basic sites. The CO2 desorption peak of CuMgFe-imp/Al2O3 and CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 exhibited the peaks α and β, while the intensity of the peak ɤ was lower than that observed for Fe-imp/Al2O3 ( Fig. 6). As shown in Table 3, the CO2 adsorption in the temperature range of 175 °C to 400 °C followed the order: CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 > CuMgFe-imp/Al2O3 > the physical mixture (CuMgFe-HT and Al2O3) > Fe/Al2O3. In Cu-containing catalysts, the CO2 adsorption associated with the β peak (175–400 °C) and the high-temperature H2 uptake (>350 °C) showed a strong correlation, as illustrated in Fig. 7. CO₂ adsorption as bidentate carbonate species was promoted by the Cu–FeOx (or MgO) interface, which was further enhanced by dispersing CuMgFe-HT on Al2O3. According to previous studies, the reduction temperature of Cu species on Al2O3 typically occurs around 250 °C, while Fe species on Al2O3 are reduced at higher temperatures, around 390 °C and 475 °C [57,58], which were consistent with those of Cu/Al2O3 and Fe/Al2O3 ( Fig. 8b). The H2-TPR profile of MgFe-HT/Al2O3 exhibited reduction peaks at 440, 575, 697, and 845 °C (Fig. 8). The reduction peak at 503 °C in Fe/Al2O3 shifted to 440 °C upon Mg incorporation via a hydrotalcite-derived structure. Furthermore, the incorporation of Mg, followed by Cu, into the hydrotalcite structure markedly enhanced reducibility. Almost reduction peaks in CuMgFe/Al2O3 were shifted to lower temperature compared to that of CuMgFe-imp/Al2O3. These results highlight that the close proximity of metal species (e.g., Cu and Mg) to Fe species is crucial for enhancing reducibility. In contrast, in bulk HT (from the physical mixture), Mg species donated electrons to other metals, as evidenced by the higher Mg binding energy compared with the impregnated catalyst (Fig. 9b). Furthermore, the Mg binding energy increased when HT was highly dispersed on Al2O3, indicating that the electron-donating effect of Mg species was further enhanced. Fig. 9c shows the Cu 2p XPS spectra of CuMgFe-imp/Al2O3, physical mixture, and CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3. The spectra exhibit two main peaks corresponding to Cu 2p3/2 (930–935 eV) and Cu 2p1/2 (950–955 eV), along with two satellite peaks at approximately 940–945 eV and 960–964 eV, respectively [60]. The binding energy of the peak assigned to Cu+ and Cu0 was higher for CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 (933.3 eV) than for the physical mixture (932.1 eV) and CuMgFe-imp/Al2O3 (932.48 eV). Furthermore, the Cu LMM Auger signal was observed at 560–580 eV [61,62], highlighting the difficulty in distinguishing Cu+ and Cu0 solely based on the Cu 2p region due to their minimal energy separation (∼0.1 eV). The Cu+/Cu0 ratio in CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 (Cu+/Cu0 = 1.8) increased compared to that in the physical mixture (Cu+/Cu0 = 0.53), in addition to CuMgFe-imp/Al2O3 (Cu+/Cu0 = 0.79), which is consistent with the results shown in Fig. 9d. As shown by H2–TPR of bulk CuMgFe-HT, Mg species in the HT enhance the reducibility of Cu via electron donation, which agrees with the present study [63]. In contrast, in the dispersed HT on Al2O3, a higher fraction of Cu exists as Cu⁺, indicating that the electron-donating effect was effectively manifested in this highly dispersed system. Interestingly, the Al species in the impregnated CuMgFe catalyst showed a more electron-rich environment than those in CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3, suggesting weaker interaction between the hydrotalcite-derived metals and the Al2O3 support. Taken together, these results demonstrate that both Mg and Cu in dispersed HT/Al2O3 contribute to electron donation, thereby improving the reducibility of Fe and promoting the formation of active Fe⁰ or Fe carbides during the reaction. 3.3 CO2 direct FT synthesis reaction Fig. 10A shows the catalytic performance for CO2 conversion and carbon distribution. Others in Fig. 10A contain alcohol and compounds not detected by GC, and the amount of the undetectable was calculated by subtracting the amount of detectable compounds from the CO2 conversion. The carbon balance was calculated for each reaction, and the results are presented as mean ± standard deviation: (a) 99.4 ± 0.28 C%, (b) 100.1 ± 0.33 C%, (c) 97.2 ± 1.37 C%, (d) 106 ± 0.8 C%, and (e) 101 ± 0.27 C%. These values indicate good closure of the carbon balance in all experiments. Alumina-supported MgFe-hydrotalcite catalyst showed no performance improvement over Fe/Al2O3; however, both CO2 conversion and C2+ hydrocarbon selectivity increased upon the addition of Cu species along with Mg. Alumina-supported CuMgFe-HT catalyst enhanced CO2 conversion and C2+ hydrocarbon selectivity, although the MgFe-type hydrotalcite catalyst showed no performance improvement over Fe/Al2O3. The performance was higher than the physical mixture (d) and the impregnated catalyst (e). The distribution of hydrocarbons produced by each catalyst followed the Anderson-Schulz-Flory (ASF) model of FTS, and the chain growth probability (α) for CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 was higher than that of the impregnated catalysts (Fig. 10B), indicating that the CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 catalyst facilitated longer carbon chain growth. According to the ASF distribution, when α = 0.62 (as observed for the CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 catalyst), the calculated selectivity toward C5–C11 hydrocarbons is approximately 35 C%. However, when the CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 catalyst was applied, the selectivity for C5–C9 hydrocarbons was 24 C%. When other components (excluding alcohols) were included together with the C5–C9 hydrocarbons, the total selectivity reached 39 C%. These results suggest that the undetected compounds are predominantly composed of hydrocarbons with carbon numbers greater than C9. In contrast, the presence of Mg species in the catalyst promotes hydrogen activation, which leads to a decrease in the olefin–to–paraffin ratio [16,65]. The long-term stability of the catalysts was evaluated over 25 h of CO2 direct Fischer–Tropsch synthesis. CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 maintained high activity throughout the reaction, whereas for the impregnated catalyst, CO2 conversion and C2+ hydrocarbons rapidly decreased within 7 h, and most of the products were CO after 25 h. TEM analysis revealed that the average size of metal species in CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 remained nearly unchanged after 5 h and 25 h of reaction (approximately 6.0 nm), whereas significant sintering was observed in the physical mixture (19.8 nm at 5 h) and in the impregnated catalyst (67 nm at 25 h). HT dispersed on Al2O3 exhibited high resistance to metal sintering compared with bulk HT and the impregnated catalyst. The diffraction peaks observed in the 40°–52° 2θ range confirm the presence of iron carbides [12,64]. The XRD patterns of CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 and CuMgFe-imp/Al2O3 exhibited weak peaks at 43.1° and 43.6°, which were assigned to Fe5C2 and Fe3C. XRD patterns after 25 h of reaction revealed that iron carbide crystalline phases (e.g., Fe3C, Fe5C2) were clearly observed in CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3, whereas only Cu- and Fe-derived crystalline phases were detected in the impregnated catalyst. Furthermore, XPS analysis after 5 h of reaction revealed the binding energy peaks at 713.6, 710.5, 708.5, 707.1 eV, and 706.6 in the Fe 2p spectrum are assigned to Fe3+ (Fe(III)), Fe2+ (Fe(II)), θ-Fe3C, Fe5C2, Fe0 respectively [57,66,67] ( Fig. 11e). Notably, the Fe carbide species were maintained after 25 h of reaction, confirming their stability under long-term reaction. The ratio of the FeCx to FeOx peak areas, as determined by XPS after 5 h of reaction, was found to be 0.048 for Fe-imp/Al2O3, 0.10 for CuMgFe-imp/Al2O3, and 0.14 for CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3, indicating a higher degree of iron carbide formation in the presence of Cu and Mg, particularly when introduced as a hydrotalcite-like structure via the in situ co-precipitation method. These results indicate that the hydrotalcite-derived catalyst not only ensures high dispersion of metal species on the Al2O3 support but also facilitates the formation and stabilization of Fe carbides, which are crucial for sustained Fischer–Tropsch activity. This may be related to the reducibility of Fe by CO. The CO–TPR profile shows CO consumption around 250–400 °C was attributed to the carburization process of metallic Fe to Fe carbides ( Fig. 12) [20,33]. The second peak above 400 °C suggests the presence of fully reduced Fe species in addition to Fe carburization. The CO consumption temperature for CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 was approximately 10 °C lower than that of the impregnated catalysts. According to previous reports, even when the difference in CO consumption temperature is approximately 10 °C, the extent of Fe5C2 species formation can vary significantly [20], suggesting that this temperature shift may still have a meaningful impact on carbide formation. Quantitative correlation analysis was performed among β-CO2 uptake, FeCx/FeOx ratio, and C5+ selectivity ( Fig. 13). A strong and statistically significant correlation was observed between the FeCx/FeOx ratio and C5+ selectivity (r = 0.9999, p = 0.0084), indicating that Fe carbide formation plays an important role in enhancing C5+ selectivity. While a high correlation was also observed between CO2 desorption and C₅⁺ selectivity (r = 0.985), the limited number of data points prevented statistical significance (p = 0.111). These results further support the importance of Fe carbide formation in promoting high C5+ selectivity. The promoted formation of Fe carbide in the hydrotalcite-derived catalyst can be ascribed to the intimate dispersion and interaction of Cu, Mg, and Fe within the layered structure, thereby facilitating C5+ hydrocarbon production from CO2. 4 Conclusion Alumina-supported CuMgFe hydrotalcite (CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3) catalyst was successfully developed for selective C2+ hydrocarbons via CO2 hydrogenation. CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 was prepared via in-situ synthesis by co-precipitation method, forming CuMgFe hydrotalcite on Al2O3. These structures appeared as needle-like and platelet-like morphologies, characteristic of CuMgFe-based hydrotalcites. Reduction of CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 resulted in the formation of metal particles with an average size of approximately 4 nm. Supporting hydrotalcite on Al2O3 inhibited particle aggregation and enhanced the external surface area. H2–TPD measurements indicated that the interface between Cu and metal oxides in the CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 catalyst was more developed than in the impregnated CuMgFe catalyst. The relationship between H2 and CO2 adsorption suggests that the increased interface between Cu and metal oxides promoted the adsorption of bidentate carbonate species. The Fe species received electron donation from the adjacent Cu and Mg species, which was further reinforced by the high dispersion of the CuMgFe-HT phase on the Al2O3 support, thereby enhancing reducibility and overall catalytic performance. CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited higher CO2 conversion of 43 %, lower CH4 selectivity of 23 C%, and higher C5+ hydrocarbons selectivity of 39 C%. Additionally, the catalyst maintained high activity throughout the 25 h reaction, whereas the impregnated catalyst exhibited rapid deactivation within 7 h, with CO becoming the predominant product. TEM analysis revealed that the metal species in CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 remained approximately 6.0 nm throughout the reaction, demonstrating high resistance to sintering. Furthermore, Fe species adjacent to Cu and MgO facilitate the formation of highly stable carbides. These synergistic effects underline the potential of CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 as a robust catalyst for long-term CO2 conversion to value-added hydrocarbons. coredata.dc:description: Fischer–Tropsch synthesis via CO2 hydrogenation represents a promising route for the direct conversion of CO2 into value-added hydrocarbons, contributing to carbon recycling and sustainable fuel production. In conventional Fe-based catalysts, alkali and alkaline earth metals function as electron promoters for Fe, enhancing Fe carbide formation and thereby facilitating the production of C2+ hydrocarbons. Furthermore, transition metals (e.g. Zn, Cu, Mn, Co) enhance carbon chain growth and improve the durability of Fe-based catalysts. This study proposes that abundant interfaces among Cu, Mg, and Fe species are crucial for enhancing CO2 conversion. An alumina-supported CuMgFe-type hydrotalcite (CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3) was developed, yielding highly dispersed metal species that formed ∼5 nm nanoparticles after reduction and providing twice the external surface area of the physical mixture (CuMgFe-HT + Al2O3). This catalyst provided a high interface of Cu and other metal oxides, improving CO2 adsorption. Moreover, the Fe species in CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 exhibited a more electron-rich state than those in impregnated CuMgFe/Al2O3, leading to enhanced reducibility of Fe. The CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 achieved a CO2 conversion of 43 %, with CH4 selectivity of 23 % and C5+ hydrocarbon selectivity of 39 %. In contrast, the impregnated CuMgFe/Al2O3 showed higher CH4 selectivity (35 %) and lower C5+ selectivity (24 %). Furthermore, CuMgFe-HT/Al2O3 inhibited the sintering of nano-metal particles and exhibited higher catalytic performance with enhanced stability. The interface between Cu and metal oxides (FeOx and MgO) contributes to the formation and maintenance of Fe carbides, enhancing C–C coupling reactions and providing active sites that can produce C5+ hydrocarbons with high stability.
